Hey, usually this issue, in my experience, is caused by a port not being open 95% of the time. Depending on your provider, the machine may have an external firewall by default (check your dashboard).

but basic way to troubleshoot this is to work backwards from the ip/port.

ip/port open -> nginx proxy configured to forward requests from open port to miner application (33333 public -> 33334 private) -> miner application set to listen on 33334 -> IP posted to chain for visibility
you should expect requests hourly around 2-3 min after the hour. If you don't see any, there is some step in that networking chain that is preventing proper comms

you'll want to be careful about ignoring this, because if your miner is connected to testnet chain (but you're trying to operate on mainnet) - it could cause other issues. the endpoint should be set in your .env

Good question!

The answer is somewhat nuanced. The data that we generate from the weather task uses microsoft aurora, which is indeed the most accurate machine learning forecast model in the world, at the moment. This model is comparable (and in some cases better) in accuracy to the IFS HRES, a numerical model provided by ECMWF, which is the "gold standard" forecasting model.

Our goal is to incentivize fine-tuning of this model in order to exceed the baseline accuracy of an already very accurate model, then provide the raw data from those outputs as a product.

Now- is this raw data easily digestible by a "normal person"? not necessarily. It is a complex set of variables that don't immediately translate to a local forecast - but all local forecast products, like what you see in your weather app, are derived from data exactly like this.

Our inital goal is to make the data available to companies that want to ingest and use it in their own products. A future goal is to create a user-facing application (like a weather app) that provides a more user-friendly display format.

I hope that helps, please let me know if you have further questions!

@qucat | Nickel5 found a nice solution to our memory leak issue which should help things significantly!

for those interested in the finer details -
many python libraries that we use implement an LRU (least recently used) cache, which can grow unbounded by default in some cases. This , combined with multiple background threads, led to an exponentially growing memory use with our heavy data load and infinitely running loops. 

We weren't aware that python leaves this cache size unbounded by default for the async module (and other invocations)  - but now we know and have made some changes which should hopefully eliminate most of our memory issues.

We'll continue to monitor for other memory leaks, but we think this was the big one causing most of our problems.
Other validators will still make their own requests and run scoring, but yes, they will sync with our team validator data hourly

We've been looking into a truly p2p/decentralized database system, but that does have some major challenges.

Basically, it requires using an additional consensus mechanism for writing data - a simple example: 3/4 of validators must agree in order for the write to execute successfully. This introduces a ton of network overhead for every single write to the database, as well as opening up avenues for data poisoning attacks.

It's still a cool idea because then we can truly share/divide workload across validators instead of replicating it, but it requires a bulletproof mechanism to ensure no cheating/malicious behavior
Please clarify.  Does  a 1_day result  scored for accuracy or only for existence or not?

day1 is scored on a comparison to the GFS model run for the same timestep.

So, essentially we do a variable-by-variable comparison to ensure that the forecast is "similar" to the GFS - ensuring that it at least reflects a global state that other official sources have posted.

Within this, there is an accuracy score (how similar is it?) - but there is also a penalty for being "too close" - you can't just submit the GFS file directly and hope for a good score, your forecast must be somewhat unique.

and by unique, i mean unique from the GFS. As it takes a lot of resources to fine tune this model, we are still allowing for base model runs to score highly right now. In the future, we will implement a "winners take all" strategy for accuracy in certain variables and regions, and the base model will not receive a high score (similar to the other tasks)

hey Gaia people! @gaia・57 

We're making a few changes to the subnet in the coming days.

We're prioritizing our weather task above anything else, including bringing on some consultants / new team members to help us turn our outputs into a compelling data product that will rival state of the art forecast products. The people we are speaking with are top experts in atmospheric physics and modeling, and we hope to have some exciting announcements soon about who we have brought onto the team and how they can drive this project to the next level.

In the short term, we will be sunsetting the other two tasks (soil moisture and DST), as the interactions between the tasks and their scoring have introduced most of the problems we have faced on the subnet side.

Here's a basic "roadmap" of the next steps we're taking. Most of these projects or goals will be happening in parallel, but we wanted to give everyone an update about where we're headed and what to expect.

1. Disable soil and geomagnetic tasks temporarily, optimize subnet operations and hyperparameters for weather task only. (this week)
2. Ground up rebuild of the subnet architecture for performance,stability, reliability. Each defined task will be more siloed and isolated from the basic operations of the subnet - think "chutes" but for geospatial tasks. (this quarter)
3. Partnership/consulting/hiring a new team member out of a few potential candidates we are speaking with, all of whom are PhD or postdoc researchers in atmospheric physics , meteorology and machine learning. The primary goal and responsibility of this person will be to refine our datasets and machine learning pipelines to produce  the most accurate and valuable outputs possible. (within the next 3 months)
4. Product infrastructure - cloud databases, payment and account systems, user-facing marketing and web applications to serve our data products and generate revenue. (within the next 3 months)

Our end goal is still in line with our whitepaper- a "mixture of experts" for geospatial tasks that extend beyond just weather. That said, in order to make it work properly within the confines of a bittensor subnet, we first need to scale back our complexity until we have rewritten the core architecture to handle it more reliably. As the weather task still has the most immediate potential, this will be our sole competition for the next few months at least.

In the future, we will again expand our task offerings to include several types* of weather tasks that all inform each other, as well as other related tasks like soil moisture prediction, etc. The end goal is a suite of data products that inform users,clients,etc about the most important geospatial data relevant to their business/industry

# update v2.4.4

- Weather task is now the sole task and competition
- This update includes some adjustments to weather scoring
- The primary change: now forecasts are scored progressively as new ground truth becomes available. There will be a set of final scores generated for 10 timesteps (every 24hr after init time), as well as initial day 1 scores. 
- the final weight calculated for a miner will be based on a lookback period of 15 days, so it will include a mixture of fully complete scoring runs, partially complete runs, and day1 scores. With everything averaged, we should get a very clear picture of who has created successful fine-tunes of the aurora model.

- what's next: 
1. detailed weather scoring metrics to be added to the website soon
2. application rewrite underway for much better scaling and scoring speed
3. website overhaul + API portal for forecasts + forecast data for sale to the general public

@gaia・57 

I have a proposal, and I know most miners will probably not love it, but we need to make some changes to our tokenomics. Just wanted to spark a discussion to see if anyone has better ideas, what they might think of our current idea, etc.

From a subnet owner perspective, you can think of miner and validator distributions/rewards as a "cost" , and the ultimate goal is to generate revenue that exceeds costs (the dollar value of all daily rewards).

While the contributions that miners and validators make are valuable - 82% of all emissions is a very high cost to pay for generating data with tons of duplication, etc. Of course, we can adjust our IM to reward only those that provide better data and we do - but this is not enough to stabilize tokenomics, especially while we're very much still in pre-revenue prototype phase as a business. We have tried very hard to *not* be like many other subnets and burn miner emissions, but that is clearly not working very well.

I think we are looking at a necessary ~50% burn to stabilize things while we are in prototype phase. I wish we had options to make this reduction on both validator and miner side, but we do not.

we can burn this ~50% in many ways - equally (easiest) , only from lower performing miners (harder to keep things fair for new miners), or by measuring those who have beat the base model like we did for older tasks, and burn it by "slot" - so each miner accounts for 1/256 of total pool - any miner which does not beat base model returns their slot to the burn key, up to 50% of the pool. The rewards are then distributed among the successful miners by regular scoring.

so many ways we could go about this, so we wanted to have an open discussion about it. Looking forward to hearing everyone's thoughts

# anti weight copier feature

- just wanted to give some details on this feature as it will result in some confusing weight behavior if you don't know how it works
- in order to discourage weight copying, we have to hurt the vtrust score of WC validators.
- since we run the weather task once per day , real scores/weights change too slowly to deter weight copiers without a very long CR3 interval (which we also don't want)

introducing: semi-random weight perturbation.

since all honest validator teams are already in sync with our database, this is quite easy:

- we generate a random seed that changes hourly, and is synced to validator databases.

- we uniformly"slice" 7% of the weight pool while still respecting scoring rank,  and distribute it randomly (using the seed) between the bottom 50% of miners which would normally have 0/almost 0 weight, and the burn key. This random distribution changes hourly along with the seed.

- why 7% ? according to our rudimentary calculations(estimations), this was the optimal amount to keep WC vtrust < .6 without affecting the incentive of higher performing miners significantly. in practice, we will just have to see how it plays out and probably make further adjustments as we go.

- along with this 7%, we will also increase the cr3 interval from 3 -> 5 to achieve our goal. If this still isnt enough, we will work on implementing yuma3/liquid alpha.

- so, if you're wondering why the weights look "noisy" - that's intentional going forward. Down with the free loaders

Could miners simply upload their GRIB prediction files to a bucket and then share the URL along with an application key that grants read-only access to validators? That way, validators wouldn’t need to run heavy compute jobs themselves—they’d just fetch the predictions directly.

Also, if a miner gets deregistered, could they re-register and still have their prediction evaluated, as long as it falls within the valid time window? That might help ensure honest contributions aren’t lost due to temporary registration issues.

this is sort of what happens already, except the base miner is configured to host the files locally. It would be relatively trivial to instead host in a bucket and provide one time URLs to the files, in fact we plan to make this an option in the future for those that don't want to figure it out themselves.

the benefit to having validators run the models is for "proof of inference" and it would make it easy to open source our progress as a subnet. The validator doesn't need to complete a full forecast run, running 1-3 steps should be enough to statistically prove that the outputs were indeed generated by that particular fine-tune. This also prevents miners from getting forecast data from other sources for a "cheap win". Thankfully, aurora base model is so good that theres pretty much only one other source that would be competitive in 10 day accuracy, and it's quite expensive.

if we went the open source route, then miners would have to publish their models + weights + build code + pipeline. Then if it exceeds base model in any category, it becomes the "model to beat" and the miner who published it receives all incentive for that category until a better model is posted. The only potential black box at that point would be the training data they sourced, if using anything else.

this would be true decentralized science, though. If we keep it the way it is, we don't really know how miners are improving, we only see their outputs. The outputs are still valuable, but I think the process is just as valuable

I don’t quite understand why the miner should act as a proxy between the bucket and the validator. On this subnet, you could have the simplest miner imaginable: it receives a timestamp for when inference should start, and then, say one hour later, it gets a second request where it simply returns the bucket URL and application key. The method of prediction and the model used shouldn’t matter—only whether the result is competitive on the network.

I also don’t get the fixation on Aurora and its fine-tuning. There are many strong models out there that can deliver excellent results. Focusing too narrowly on one model could limit innovation and diversity in approaches.

Additionally, publishing your own pipelines seems questionable. If someone has invested time and effort into developing a robust pipeline, why should they be expected to give it away for free, just so other miners can copy their work? That could discourage meaningful contributions and penalize those who push the boundaries.

We're not only fixated on aurora, our scoring system should handle any model just fine. Its just the most promising one in our opinion (and also much easier to fine tune/ extend than graphcast, for example)

the reward would still go to miners if we required them to publish their pipelines, and we get the benefit of incentivizing progress in this research area so that we don't get some miner/team that goes far and beyond what most could achieve, but keeps it to themselves and dominates without pressure to continue improving. Think of it as incentivizing open source progress, not just capitalizing on what already exists (which btw, is open source) and privatizing anything on top of it.

why do academics publish papers at all? or maybe they wait till they have a patent first, but its pretty tricky to patent software. I think this is more of a discussion of morality and beliefs and its also not something we'd have implemented any time soon.

personally, I like the idea of requiring it to be open sourced, so that we put incentive pressure on advancing the technology for the greater benefit of humanity, and not just enriching a few smart people.

plus, there are still aspects to any pipeline/fine tune that would be very hard to force miners to include - like datasets. Maybe the input is still just GFS, but you fine tune using some other cherry picked dataset. That would act as a moat for miners, since it's probably the most important aspect of a fine tune anyways. and unless we also validate the entire fine-tune (expensive) we cant prove which data was or was not used

The main point is that academics receive funding regardless of outcome, whereas we as miners have a limited number of attempts, tests, and resources. On top of that, if you’re not the top performer, the incentive you receive is so small that it doesn’t come close to covering your costs. So comparing us to academics isn’t really fair—especially since, as a solo miner, you typically have very limited resources. And if you’re part of a team, you need to generate revenue to sustain operations.

also to clarify what i meant by the open source idea-

yes, the pipeline + weights would need to be published, but the replication would only need to be proven in inference, not in training. So if you use any other dataset in your fine-tune/training, that wouldn't need to be included. the data and method is the moat.

then, we have a winner-takes-all slot for ~15-25 categories: best model in specific variables, climate classifications, etc. some models may win in more than one category at once.

the miner/hotkey that posted the model receives 95%-100% of the allocated reward for that slot until it is replaced by a better model. the other 5% rewards go to hosting inference, if necessary.

benefits of this for the subnet/product:
- all miners can host inference for the best models, instead of just 1 miner per model
- we keep things consistently competitive and progressing, we don't stagnate in our outputs

benefits for the miner:
- there are very few miners in bittensor even capable of producing fine tunes that could exceed SOTA. If you get a slot, you're probably gonna be holding it for a long time. Even if your code/weights/input pipeline is public, its not trivial for another miner to copy and improve upon it quickly because they don't know your data sources (besides input for inference) or your methodology. Its basically just a hint to say - "hey, this direction was successful"
- similarly, if you do NOT own a reward slot, you don't have to start from scratch to catch up to better models, you at least have some idea of where to go to be competitve

I totally hear your side and I even agree that open sourcing might not be the most effective strategy as a business, but I also don't think privatized black-box subnets fit with the ethos of bittensor very well either. If we're trying to create a decentralized alternative to mega AI corps, open sourcing seems like part of that solution

As for open source software companies, they mostly profit from their reputation and the quality of their ancillary services. They can afford to go open-source. But on weather subnet, if someone steals your SOTA model, you’re left with nothing to offer.

The question about directed revenue is tricky—and I can already imagine the “gotcha” moment: “So you don’t care about the subnet, just the money?” 😄 But yes, I’d prefer revenue to go directly to the miner. Why should I pump the subnet and then share the earnings indirectly with validators?

Hey all! Just wanted to give a quick update about what changes are coming soon:

As some of you may know, we experienced issues this week related to a DDoS on our validator from ~20 different IP addresses, spamming connection attempts to our (public) subnet ip/port and via SSH. We've mitigated this particular problem successfully, but it made it clear that our validator machine and the current architecture just aren't capable of handling spikes in network load effectively, and even without DDoS we have been hitting the upper limits of what our application could handle as more miners successfully answer the weather task (up to 100+ last I saw). These load issues were not apparent earlier because so few miners were answering the task previously, and testnet with 2 active miners obviously wouldn't make this clear either.

SO, while we've been working on a comprehensive stats module for everyone to display results, we got a bit carried away and redesigned our core validator architecture out of pure spite and frustration. Much to our surprise, we've gotten it mostly working much faster than we could have anticipated - thanks to raw willpower and a few too many dollars spent on Anthropic API credits (the era of VC subsidized LLMs is quickly approaching its end) .

It's still messy and needs bug testing, evaluation and cleanup, but we anticipate that we will be able to release this major upgrade as soon as **next week.**

so here's what's changing :

## Gaia V.2.9.9 - Coming next week
- Why the version skip? because this isn't polished enough to be 3.0.0, but its basically 3.0.0 beta

- Simplification of the weather pipeline: instead of a complicated multi-step process , we have simplified the request flow. Validator queries with GFS timesteps -> miner starts inference and prepares files -> validator checks files and scores. Thanks to @sarna320   for a good conversation and some inspiration here. This reduces the number of potential failure points significantly.

- Validator will now process miners independently after seeding a forecast run and downloading the scoring/input data.  This independent processing will drastically increase resilience, the current system waits for entire batches to complete before moving to the next step, which can slow down the whole flow significantly and introduce more opportunities for failure.

- How is this accomplished? in short, the new architecture is a job queue/ state manager / multiprocess worker paradigm. Each individual miner forecast flow has strictly managed state transitions which spawn new jobs upon completion of the previous step. Workers are initialized on validator startup and scale to match ~80% of machine core count. Other jobs like cleanup, deregistration, etc are also managed through the same job system. This significantly reduces the overload on the main event loop and ensures more reliability, as workers can crash/recover/retry independently without bringing an entire forecast run (or the whole validator application) to a halt.

- In our initial testing, this new system is FAST and reliable. Miners will get a maximum of 3 retries with an exponential backoff for each networking step, in case of failures or connection issues. Since every miner is processed independently, a single miner failure/retry wont slow down the whole run.

- The statistics module will include 3 new tables that are streamed to our web server and Grafana plugin, covering a broad variety of general per-miner stats, all the way down to specific forecast runs and their component scores, as well as logging of any failures in networking steps. Once this is all displayed, it should be trivial to analyze your own performance, other miners performance, and the overall performance of subnet outputs.

- This update will require that ALL miners and validators pull the latest code, as the networking protocol is changing. If you do not update your code, you will not be scored correctly.

# v2.9.9 update

## BETA for 3.0.0

__Architecture overhaul__

- Single event loop —> multiprocessing workers, job queue, separation of responsibilities
- Batch processing/retries/recoveries —> individual processing and scoring pipelines that operate independently for each miner
- Vectorized calculations, cache layers, other performance optimizations 
- Major increase in per-variable scoring metrics
- Final (ERA5) scoring: 9 variables —> 69 variable/pressure level combos (nice)

__Increased reliability and resilience__
- Miners can fail and retry individually while having minimal impact on the overall forecast run.
- No more delayed runs, failed runs, manual restarts and retries
- (Hopefully) - We’ll see what it looks like when we throw terabytes of data at it on mainnet. Theoretically and in testing, this is much better. 

__Main Validator Database Viewer (launching shortly)__
- Peruse scoring metrics and validator data to your hearts content
- Each miner generates ~700 component scores for every single forecast. Dive deep into a full statistical mapping of the atmosphere from ground level to the stratosphere. Identify specific pressure level and variable combinations that need improvement, compare them with other miners, you name it.  

## MINERS AND VALIDATORS MUST UPDATE
- Protocol has changed, if you don't update you will not be scored
- `git pull` , `pip install -r requirements.txt` , `pip install -e .` , `pm2 delete [validator process]`, recreate process


Additional Notes:
- database has been wiped : everyone starting from square 1
- some metrics columns are not populated yet. We will be adding additional calculations and columns over the coming weeks for (even more) comprehensive stats
- we will monitor closely for errors/unexpected behavior, please share any you may encounter

Just wanted to give everyone a heads up now that things are starting to settle and all is running smooth and we're confident that validators can effectively handle the full data load-

We're soon going to change the scoring mech to be a lot more "strict"

We will encourage/incentivize fine tuning to improve accuracy in certain variables/climate regions, etc. We also will incentivize diversity around the mean as we begin constructing our ensemble datasets, so use of other models besides microsoft aurora will also be encouraged and rewarded! (deepmind's graphcast + gencast, pangu, aardvark, etc)

Once this is implemented, miners running the base model (or anything that has equal or lesser accuracy) will NOT receive a score at all. Any miner emissions not allocated to miners achieving verifiable increases over the base model will be burned (wouldn't be surprised if this initially results in a near total burn)

currently, there's only one miner that is achieving a slight increase over the base model score, and this is only on day1 scoring, so it remains to be seen if their fine tune will maintain high performance throughout the entire scoring period. If they maintain higher accuracy for a full 10day scoring, this is a significant achievement!

We will likely be 2-4 weeks out on rolling this out, so I just wanted to give everyone a decent heads up so they can begin experimenting and working on their fine tunes. 

We will  soon be talking with some local organizations with specialized data needs (think niche applications instead of general forecasting) , so we will also likely include incentive bonuses for fine tuning for those specializations. Hint - its going to be a good idea to tune for mountainous regions, near term accuracy, and perhaps consider building pipelines to ingest real-time observational data that can be incorporated at inference time

Hi! To be honest i don't see the point of day 1 scoring at all and since you don't check against the ground truth. Where am I wrong?

point is - for quality control and some immediate feedback on forecast submission. Without immediate score (however slight it may be) we open ourselves up to more sybil attack/mass reg type behavior.

There are other ways we could approach this, however - like doing hindcasting on era5 data that is already available as a QC step. The risk of using this method for model evaluation is that some miners will do anything to cheat rather than contributing honestly, and hindcasting opens up the possibility that someone will submit a perturbed era5 for high score with low effort.

@Crispy_ [𝞃, 𝞃] separately suggested that we evaluate day1 with a blended average of GFS + IFS, which would help to prevent cheating, but it's still not foolproof.

if we removed it entirely, miners would be waiting 5-6 days to receive any score, which would require us to increase the immunity period , making it easier to mass register and push others out.
The only way i see this solution working well is to require significant collateral (1T or more) like some other subnets do (SN8, SN51) so it would be very expensive to mass register.

I'll take a closer look but here's what happened:
- I recalculated almost all scores from existing runs last night from scratch, so some miners which may have failed at a communication step had a chance to be re-scored as long as they were still registered and hosting the forecast files.

Ok, let me clarify. 

There's no issue that the recalculated scores include the "exploiting scores" again, because they no longer directly correspond to weight after the second patch I pushed. It's now mostly a helpful metric for miners to see how they compare to the GFS. So a miner with an "exploiting score" of .9999 will receive no more benefit to their overall weight than one with a base model score of .39 - they both receive 5% on the total score for that individual forecast run.

Not all scores were recalculated, because it wasn't necessary to duplicate many of those calculations. Only those that got corrupted as I was changing the era5 data system needed to be recalculated.

So - now you will be able to see that exploiting day 1 does not translate to a better era5 score, as opposed to removing that score row entirely. We are still scoring these forecasts regularly, but there is no longer a benefit to them having submitted the GFS - in fact, it will most likely drag down their average score as era5 begins for those runs
